channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Many Developed Countries View Online Misinformation as ‘Major Threat’
item.description: New research from the Pew Research Center shows nearly three-quarters of respondents are very concerned about the spread of false information online.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson

item.title: Snap Lays Off 20% of Employees and Restructures
item.description: The maker of Snapchat discontinued some of its products and appointed a chief operating officer, amid financial struggles.
item.dc:creator: Kalley Huang
item.media:description: Layoffs at Snap, which makes the Snapchat app, will affect close to 1,300 of its 6,400 workers.

item.title: Google Says Trump’s Truth Social Must Scrub Violent Content to Join Play Store
item.description: The social media app is not available on Google’s app store, and the former president’s company and Google are publicly disagreeing about why.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant

item.title: Elon Musk Cites Twitter Whistleblower Report as Reason to Scrap Deal
item.description: The billionaire said in a letter to Twitter that allegations made by a whistle-blower have had a “material, if not existential” effect on the company.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch and Kate Conger
item.media:description: Elon Musk has said Twitter’s disclosures about the number of fake accounts on the platform were misleading.

item.title: Doug Mastriano’s Extremely Online Rise to Republicans’ Governor Nominee in Pa.
item.description: The G.O.P. candidate for governor of Pennsylvania deftly used Facebook to build a loyal right-wing fan base at the height of the pandemic. Will it be enough to win a competitive general election?
item.dc:creator: Charles Homans
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Although Doug Mastriano is perhaps better known for challenging the results of the 2020 presidential election, he built a loyal following with pandemic livestreams on Facebook.

item.title: Some Carmakers Say Recycling Car Parts Is the Future. But Is It Realistic?
item.description: “Circular manufacturing” has the promise to reduce waste by reusing parts to make new cars. There are glimmers of hope, but they are currently outweighed by challenges.
item.dc:creator: Roy Furchgott

item.title: Google Employee Who Played Key Role in Protest of Contract With Israel Quits
item.description: The worker said the company had tried to retaliate against her activism opposing a deal with the Israeli military, while co-workers argued the company had an anti-Palestinian bias.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant
item.category: From the River to the Sea: Palestine and Israel in the Shadow of "Peace" (Book)
item.media:credit: Geloy Concepcion for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ariel Koren, a marketing manager at Google, opposed Project Nimbus because she was concerned that the company’s technology could help the Israeli Defense Forces surveil and harm Palestinians.

item.title: The Animal Translators
item.description: Scientists are using machine learning to eavesdrop on naked mole rats, fruit bats, crows and whales — and to communicate back.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Felix Schmitt for The New York Times
item.media:description: Naked mole rats live in large, underground colonies and have an elaborate vocal repertoire.

item.title: California Approves Bill to Punish Doctors Who Spread False Information
item.description: Weighing into the fierce national debate over Covid-19 prevention and treatments, the state would be the first to try a legal remedy for vaccine disinformation.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers
item.media:description: California’s Legislature approved a bill that would allow regulators to punish doctors for spreading false information about Covid-19 vaccinations and treatments.

item.title: FTC Sues Over Tracking Data That Could Expose Visits to Abortion Clinics
item.description: Federal regulators said the sale of geolocation information on tens of millions of smartphones could expose people’s visits to private places.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:description: Civil rights groups have warned that law enforcement agencies could obtain smartphone locations of women seeking abortions and use the data to prosecute them.

item.title: Did My Cat Just Hit On Me? An Adventure in Pet Translation
item.description: Entrepreneurs are aiming to put A.I.-powered pet translation tools into our pockets.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Elon Musk’s Lawyers Subpoena Twitter Whistle-Blower
item.description: Peiter Zatko’s accusations of false statements and security shortcomings at Twitter may be used by Mr. Musk in the legal battle over a $44 billion acquisition of the company.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:description: Elon Musk has said Twitter’s disclosures about the number of fake accounts on the platform were misleading.

item.title: Honda and LG will jointly build a U.S. battery plant.
item.description: The announcement comes as the auto industry ramps up its efforts to switch to electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: A Honda electric vehicle on display at the Central China Auto Show last month.

item.title: Recycled Metals From Electronic Waste Used to Make Jewelry
item.description: More jewelers, large and small, are using precious metals recovered from electronic waste.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Bumpus

item.title: Silicon Valley’s Elite Get Dragged Into Musk-Twitter Trial
item.description: More than 100 subpoenas have been issued to techies like Jack Dorsey and Marc Andreessen as Twitter tries to force Elon Musk to complete a $44 billion deal. Law firms are stoked.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger

item.title: Xi Jinping’s Vision for Tech Self-Reliance in China Runs Into Reality
item.description: After heavy national investment in semiconductors to break a dependence on global chips, Mr. Xi seems unhappy with the results.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan

item.title: Taiwan Is Caught in a Great Game Over Microchips
item.description: Worried about the Chinese threat to Taiwan, the U.S. and others have tried to expand their piece of the island’s semiconductor production.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, John Liu and Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company factory in Nanjing, China.

item.title: On Truth Social, QAnon Accounts Found a Home and Trump’s Support
item.description: Researchers identified 88 users promoting the conspiracy theory on Donald Trump’s platform, and said he had reposted messages 65 times.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany Hsu
item.media:description: A QAnon sweatshirt at a pro-Trump rally in October 2020 in New York City.

item.title: A Journey Into Misinformation on Social Media
item.description: Disinformation and misinformation on social media have only grown worse since the 2016 election, our reporters say. And the threat is changing faster than the social media companies can keep up.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell, Sheera Frenkel, Tiffany Hsu and Stuart A. Thompson
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Merchandise in Prescott, Ariz., before a rally by former President Donald J. Trump. About 70 percent of Republicans suspect that fraud took place in the 2020 presidential election.

item.title: The Crypto World Can’t Wait for Ethereum’s ‘Merge’
item.description: A long-awaited upgrade to Ethereum, the most popular crypto platform, may make the technology more environmentally sustainable. But it comes with risks.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany

item.title: What Is ‘the Merge’?
item.description: Here’s what to know about a major software upgrade to Ethereum, the most popular crypto platform.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany

item.title: California E.V. Mandate Finds a Receptive Auto Industry
item.description: The move to phase out gasoline-powered cars, with other states expected to follow, matches automakers’ plans. The challenge will be making it happen.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A charging station in Burbank, Calif. Tesla has been a leader in the transition to electric vehicles, but established automakers are in hot pursuit.

item.title: Remote Scan of Student’s Room Before Test Violated His Privacy, Judge Rules
item.description: A federal judge said Cleveland State University violated the Fourth Amendment when it used software to scan a student’s bedroom, a practice that has grown during the Covid-19 pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch and April Rubin
item.media:description: Programs that can remotely monitor students’ keystrokes and feeds from their cameras have become more popular during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Why Peloton Is Selling on Amazon
item.description: The dream was to sell directly to customers. Now Peloton is on Amazon, Casper is in a furniture shop, and it’s awkward.
item.dc:creator: Shira Ovide

item.title: Spiders Are Caught in a Global Web of Misinformation
item.description: Researchers looked at thousands of spider news stories to study how sensationalized information spreads. Their findings could be broadly applicable.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang

item.title: Peloton Reports a $1.2 Billion Loss as Sales Slow
item.description: The maker of exercise bikes attributed part of the loss to restructuring charges related to supply chain and inventory problems.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:description: Peloton has lost money for six straight quarters.

item.title: Judge John Hodgman on Taking the Chargers
item.description: A family disagrees on whether the electronic accessory should be communal or not.
item.dc:creator: John Hodgman

item.title: Facebook, Twitter and Others Remove Pro-U.S. Influence Campaign
item.description: It was the first time that an influence operation promoting U.S. interests abroad had been discovered and taken down from the social media platforms.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Tiffany Hsu
item.media:description: Meta and Twitter said they were removing accounts associated with an influence campaign that promoted U.S. foreign policy interests abroad.

item.title: Twitter executives push back against whistle-blower complaint.
item.description: The narrative created by the company’s former head of security is “false,” executives said at an all-hands meeting.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac and Kate Conger
item.media:description: “This complaint that was filed yesterday is foundationally, technically and historically inaccurate,” the Twitter chief executive, Parag Agrawal, said Wednesday.

item.title: Google Looks to Vaccination to Combat Misinformation In Searches
item.description: British researchers and a team from Google found that teaching people how to spot misinformation made people more skeptical of it.
item.dc:creator: Nico Grant and Tiffany Hsu
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: The strategies and tools being deployed during this year’s midterm vote often resemble those used to combat misinformation in past elections.

item.title: Why Andrew Tate’s Social Media Accounts Are Being Removed
item.description: TikTok, YouTube and Facebook have taken down accounts belonging to Mr. Tate, a 35-year-old British American.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: Peloton Will Sell Fitness Equipment and Apparel on Amazon
item.description: The deal, which will help expand distribution of its stationary bikes, comes in the middle of a turnaround effort by the company’s new chief executive.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Schmidt
item.media:description: Peloton’s Amazon deal is its first attempt to sell products outside its direct-to-consumer model.
